newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - July 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - July 25.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Cambodia's foreign minister has told his ASEAN counterparts the events of July 5 and 6 have been legitimate and Phnom Penh will stand by the 1991 Paris Peace Accords. The events did not represent fighting between the Cambodian People's Party and Funcinpec, Ung Huot told the 30th ASEAN ministers' meeting. (BANGKOK POST)

- Coalition parties are unhappy with the draft charter but are reluctant to say outright whether they will vote for or against it for fear of going against public opinion. Only the key opposition Democrat Party has said it will endorse the draft despite its disagreement with several provisions. Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, the New Aspiration leader, has been non-committal, saying only that he will rather allow his party members a free vote. (BANGKOK POST, THE NATION)

- The state should scrap the Hopewell contract and build the mass transit system itself or find other parties, the Transport and Communications Ministry suggests. A panel monitoring the project concludes the state should scrap the 30-year contract with the consent of Hopewell (Thailand) Co. (BANGKOK POST)

- The 16 suspended finance firms will be allowed to engage in revenue generating activities but may not redeem promissory notes after the end of the period of suspension. The Bank of Thailand and the Finance Ministry ordered the 16 companies to be suspended for 30 days on June 27. The order also required that rehabilitation plans be submitted for approval. (BUSINESS DAY)

- Thailand is considering borrowing from the International Monetary Fund or Japan, the finance minister confirms. After weeks of speculation the country would borrow $10-$20 billion to help the cash-strapped economy, Thanong Bidaya would only say the ministry was considering asking for unspecified loans. (BANGKOK POST)
